comment: A note for people who's watching this video. There are some bits of outdated information here.    When ethernet first came out, there was only a single cable medium for communication(which is discussed in the video).  Later, Radia Perlman developed Spanning tree protocol with which such single cable mediums can be interconnected witha device such as switch and STP aimed to handle the loops in the system. There's a talk by her somewhere on YouTube about this.

The collision happens if B starts transmitting just slightly before 1st bit of the frame sent by A reaches B. there won't be any collision involving Frames Of A and B if B has alrady recieved even a single Bit from A's frame as It won't start transmitting It's frame before the last bit Of A's frame is received and the link is Idle. Timestamp 8:58

An excellent video . You really made my studying interesting and easy . Thanks a lot brother. Keep doing lots of videos . You have a great wisdom in teaching... Hope to see a lots of subjects handled by you. Thanks again...

At 9.10 c point: How will b begin transmitting before the last bit is received, the channel is not idle b start transmitting when all the 200 bits are received so no collision, if u wanted collision b needed to send data before it receives 1stbit from a because till that time it will assume channel idle.
